scriptLines.text: The elmwood tinted rays of the sun cast long shadows against the well-used trail, as you cross the paths of travelling merchants, pilgrims, and, to your surprise, a fellow hired blade - with a battle-axe of some impressive make.
They're dressed rather ostentatiously in fine cloths and silks, their armor light but of just as high quality as their weapon.
You can't tell if they're a man or a woman even when they speak, their husky voice just as ambiguous; the androgyny persists even when they introduce themselves as "Trudy".
"And you?" they ask, looking you up and down, clearly taking note of your inferior armaments and accoutraments.

"Hail, Trudy.  My name is <NAME>," you say, trying your best to sound authoritative, although the way they stare off, enmeshed in their own thoughts, makes you wonder how much they actually care what your name is.

"<NAME>, is it?  Hmph.  Well then, <NAME>, the day grows long.  If you'd accompany me for dinner, I would be willing to share," they say, and, feeling the growling of your own stomach, and a desire for a friendly face after so long alone, you agree.

You share a meal around a campfire, surrounded by leagues of grass, with the dark forests hiding the sleeping sun.  Trudy smiles at your jokes and regales you with tales of their heroism, noting that their axe has taken the heads of ogres and minotaurs alike.
"So, then..." they say, resting their finger under your chin, "would you like to spend the night with me?"

"Just to be clear... you are a man, yes?" they ask, and when you nod, they sigh.  "Hm.  I see."
"Are... you?" you ask, and they blink.
"Am I... what?"
You scratch your head.  There's no delicate way to say it.  "A man?"
Trudy's jaw drops.  "I- you- of COURSE I am!  I've... argh!" he says, stomping over to collect his things.
He shoots you an indignant glance as he takes up his axe, hoisting it over his shoulder, and he leaves in a huff, apparently quite annoyed.
You encounter Trudy again in the woods - their cheeks redden as you approach.
"I could use your help," he says, and after he explains the situation, you agree to lend your metal.

Seeing an opportunity to make some much-needed travelling coin, you join Trudy on his treasure hunt.

You scout out the warg together, and he details his plan, which is simple: he'll distract the beast while you loot the body, and then you'll reconvene at a pre-arranged meeting place - Trudy's camp.  He's confident of his technique, but in the worst case...

"It's a fearsome beast... but it's their mating season, and it seems there are no female wargs around.  It doesn't seem to have a taste for humans, if the state of our noble is any indication," he says, as you watch the warg gnawing on a bone, the fallen noble decaying next to him.
There doesn't seem to be any obvious external injuries - you wonder what did the poor guy in, but it doesn't seem it was the warg itself, despite its hulking, dangerous appearance.
After making note of the area surrounding the warg's den, the two of you make your way back to Trudy's camp, where you leave the bulk of your heaviest gear so as to be more mobile.
You spend the night in Trudy's camp, sharing a meal again.

You notice it - a snare.  Tied to a hefty rock, it seems. It would take some time for a person to be free of it, were it to snare their leg.  It wasn't there when you passed by earlier, for certain, or one of you would have doubtless tripped it.
You stop walking... and notice that Trudy stops half a pace behind you.  Their gaze flicks over to the snare for but a moment, then meets yours.
"W-What's the matter? Do you hear something?" they say, and you can tell that they're feigning ignorance.
"It's behind you!" you shout, and Trudy spins to face the threat, taking a wide backstep... thus triggering the snare.
You decide to step over it.
You shake your head, and motion to step over the wire.
As Trudy's axe handle trips the snare, you manage to dodge the rope at the last moment... causing his leg to get caught in it.
Trudy's axe handle trips the snare, and your trailing foot is caught in it!
